awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2018, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The Fellow will investigate the genetic mechanisms and evolutionary forces shaping the differences between males and females, which are fundamental to the origins and maintenance of biological diversity. The Fellow will leverage the natural variation in the chromosomes that determine male vs. female in geckos to test classic evolutionary theory. The chromosomes that determine male vs. female are specialized chromosomes that trigger male or female development, and occur in two major systems. In XX/XY systems like humans, XY individuals are male, but in ZZ/ZW systems, ZW individuals are female. This fundamental difference in inheritance has sparked major theoretical predictions about the contrasting genetic mechanisms and evolutionary pressures shaping XY versus ZW systems. The Fellow will use geckos, which have evolved XY and ZW systems multiple times, to examine untested classical predictions using a novel and state-of-the-art comparative approach. The Fellow will broaden student participation in bioinformatics activities that explore genome biology and computational science, and will develop networking opportunities for underrepresented students seeking international research experience.

XY/XX and ZW/ZZ chromosomes arise as recombination is suppressed between a pair of autosomes, which subsequently diverge from one another in sequence and expression. Theory predicts key differences in the evolution of XY and ZW chromosomes and the roles they play in adaptation, dimorphism and speciation. In geckos, XY and ZW systems have evolved independently upwards of 17 times. The Fellow will conduct a comparative analysis of XX/XY and ZZ/ZW chromosome evolution using multiple independently evolved gecko XY and ZW systems. The Fellow will test the role of chromosomal inversions in recombination suppression between these chromosomes, and how cessation of recombination differs between XY and ZW systems. Next, the Fellow will investigate how recombination, selection, and drift shape divergence in these chromosomes. Finally, the Fellow will study the evolution of XX/XY and ZZ/ZW biased gene expression and how this process differs between XY and ZW systems. Together, these studies build an integrated mechanistic view of XX/XY and ZZ/ZW chromosome evolution and the fundamental forces acting across the entire genome. The Fellow will develop cutting-edge skills in research, mentoring, and communication, and will engage diverse audiences in genome evolution and global research opportunities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit:

The projects developed during this Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology aimed to increase understanding of genome evolution, with a specific focus on the genetic basis of sexual variation. In many species, sexual development is triggered by specialized chromosomes called sex chromosomes. However, given the fundamental nature of sexual development and reproduction for many animals and plants, a surprising amount of diversity exists in sex chromosome systems. The work conducted with this fellowship investigated the evolutionary forces shaping sex chromosomes by leveraging the diversity found within treehoppers, a group of insects comprising the family Membracidae. This work sampled 23 treehopper species from North and South America for whole genome DNA sequencing, generating the first DNA sequence data for many of these species. Ongoing analyses are revealing the identity and genomic location of sex chromosomes across species. Preliminary evidence suggests that there may be chromosomal rearrangements contributing to shifts in sex chromosome composition and identity among species. Future analyses will test the evolutionary forces driving these changes, and functional changes (such as shifts in gene expression) accompanying sex chromosome turnover among species. 

In parallel to this work, two publications were generated that address methodological aspects of the research themes above. The first reviewed current bioinformatic methods for identifying sex chromosomes from whole-genome sequence data, and discussed ongoing technical challenges and open questions in sex chromosome research. The second publication reviewed methods for assessing signatures of natural selection on gene expression data, and highlighted major challenges of this work. 

During this fellowship I also investigated gene expression evolution in birds. Whereas most studies of gene expression focus on differences in expression levels, another mechanism (known as alternative splicing) can also produce variation in gene expression. In this project, we analyzed how patterns of alternative splicing vary between males and females in multiple bird species, finding that sex differences in alternative splicing may play an important role in sex-specific adaptation.

Broader impacts:

I organized a working group of PhD students, postdocs, and faculty in my home department to critically assess and re-envision the department's undergraduate curriculum. This work was motivated by student calls to make the curriculum more socially aware and better contextualize the connections between science and society. As a result of this work, we created resources to help instructors incorporate social context into their courses, with the goal of engaging a broader student population. Over a dozen faculty in the department actively participated in this project, revising their course content using the working group?s resources. Our group was invited to share this work with other departments and universities through several invited talks.

I also collaborated on a project that examines the legacies of imperialism and colonialism in science practices. We compiled a dataset of bird species descriptions from 1950-2019, and analyzed patterns of authorship and naming practices, particularly focusing on species that are named after people. We found global disparities in naming practices that reflect the broad geopolitical context of scientific work. This project was published as a preprint manuscript on bioRxiv and reached a broad audience via social media, reflecting a widespread desire in the biology community to reflect on and reimagine science practices. 

Finally, the projects developed under this fellowship contributed to securing an Assistant Professor position at the University of Texas at Arlington. The work described above forms the basis of my ongoing research program and will drive future proposals to continue investigating genome evolution, sex chromosome evolution, and the connections between science and society.
